awd_titl_txt: The Effect of Pictures in Books for Beginning Readers: Attention Allocation, Reading Fluency, and Reading Comprehension in K-2 Students
awd_abstract_narration:
The practice of using illustrations in materials for teaching children to read dates back over 250 years. In recent years, illustrations in books for beginning readers have become increasingly more colorful and engaging than in the past. Yet, there is virtually no research evaluating the effect of close proximity of text to colorful engaging illustrations on emerging literacy skills. However, there are theoretical and empirical reasons to believe that engaging colorful illustrations placed in close proximity to text in books for beginning readers may interfere with (rather that aid) emerging literacy skills. This research will examine (1) whether close proximity of text to illustrations, a typical layout in books for beginning readers, creates competition for attentional resources, thus interfering with reading fluency and comprehension; and (2) how the layout of books for beginning readers can be optimized to reduce competition for attentional resources and thus improve fluency and comprehension in beginning readers. 

To address these questions, this project will use portable eye tracking devices to examine the patterns of attention allocation as children in kindergarten through second grade read books designed for beginning readers. Specifically, researchers will measure the number of gaze shifts from text to illustrations and the total time children spend looking at text and illustrations. It is hypothesized that frequent gaze shifts from text to illustrations are indicative of children being distracted by illustrations. Additionally, researchers will collect measures of reading fluency and reading comprehension. In a series of six studies, researchers will compare performance on measures of attention and reading when children read commercially available books to modified versions of the same books. The modifications to commercially available books will be aimed at optimizing the layout of text and illustrations to reduce competition for attentional resources. It is predicted that modified book layouts will lead to decreased frequency of gaze shifts from text to illustrations, and increased reading fluency and comprehension. Overall, this project has potential to uncover low-cost and easy to scale basic principles to achieve optimal design of reading materials to improve literacy skills of beginning readers.

por.por_cntn:
The practice of using illustrations in materials for teaching children to read dates back over 250 years. These illustrations are often detailed, colorful, engaging, and placed in close proximity to the text. Despite being wide-spread in the Western culture, there are only a handful of studies that evaluated the effects of engaging illustrations placed in close proximity to text on emerging literacy skills. However, there are theoretical reasons to believe that placement of engaging illustrations in close proximity to difficult-to-decode text creates competition for attentional resources. This competition may be particularly challenging to resolve for beginning readers because attention regulation is still immature in elementary school-age children. This project used eye tracking technology and commercially available reading materials designed for reading practice in beginning readers to explore how the design of reading materials for beginning readers may affect attention regulation, and thereby emerging literacy skills. This project provided first direct evidence that (1) extraneous illustration details in reading materials for beginning readers induce attentional competition and lead to reduced reading comprehension; and that (2) reading materials for beginning reader scan be designed to optimize attention and comprehension in a way that (3) does not interfere with children’s enjoyment of reading materials. 

 

Broader implications of the outcomes of this project include direct implications for the design of reading materials for beginning readers and pedagogical implications for reading instruction. The project also afforded numerous opportunities for engaging in discussing science with educators, caregivers, and other members of the public. Finally, over the life of the project, it provided research training opportunities to 8 graduate students (3 from underrepresented minority groups), 10 non-student research assistants (2 from underrepresented minority groups), and 45 undergraduate students (13 from underrepresented minority groups). Therefore, this project made significant contributions to broadening participation in STEM and to training the next generation of researchers.
